qas.question: What are the four common styles of mandolins?

answers.text: the Neapolitan or round-backed mandolin, the carved-top mandolin and the flat-backed mandolin.

qas.question: What is the round-back mandolin made of?

answers.text: strips of wood, glued together into a bowl

qas.question: Which style of mandolin has a shallower, arched back, and arched top?

answers.text: European classical music and traditional music.

context: There are many styles of mandolin, but four are common, <a0_0>the <b9_0>Neapolitan or round-backed mandolin, the carved-top mandolin and the flat-backed mandolin<b9_0/>.<a0_0/> The <a2_0><b5_0><b11_0>round-back<b11_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/> has a deep bottom, constructed of <a1_0><b10_0>strips of wood, glued together into a bowl<b10_0/><a1_0/>. The <b6_0>carved-top or arch-top mandolin<b6_0/> has a much shallower, arched back, and an arched top—both carved out of wood. The flat-backed mandolin uses thin sheets of wood for the body, braced on the inside for strength in a similar manner to a guitar. Each style of instrument has its own sound quality and is associated with particular forms of music. Neapolitan mandolins feature prominently in <a3_0><b8_0><b12_0>European classical music and traditional music<b12_0/><b8_0/>.<a3_0/> <a4_0><b13_0>Carved-top instruments<b13_0/><a4_0/> are common in <b7_0>American folk music and bluegrass<b7_0/> music. Flat-backed instruments are commonly used in Irish, British and Brazilian folk music. Some modern Brazilian instruments feature an extra fifth course tuned a fifth lower than the standard fourth course.
